title: How to Easily Find & Make Friends as an Adult

steps.title: Sign up for a class.
steps.content: Sign up for a class. Attending a workshop or class can help you meet new people with similar interests! May you join a cooking class to fulfill your Hell’s Kitchen fantasies, or perhaps you sign up for a dance class to please your inner child. [1] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Keep social event specialist Kevin Wang’s advice in mind: “Being active and finding hobbies and events that are social in nature will help you meet new people by sheer exposure. Finding common ground through interests and activities will then help you solidify the bond with new friends.”

steps.title: Volunteer in your local area.
steps.content: Volunteer in your local area. Helping others is a great way to meet new people and give back to your community. Plus, the habit of volunteering can help you engage with different types of people and improve social skills. [2] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Simply search “volunteer opportunities near me” to find a project to dedicate some time to. Pro tip: Ask your local library, food bank, hospital, or school if there are any volunteer opportunities you could be a part of.

steps.title: Join a gym.
steps.content: Join a gym. Why not build those muscles while making new friends? If you’re all about fitness or want to break into the lifestyle, consider joining a gym. Participate in classes and start going at a set time. You’ll likely find that more than one face will become familiar!

steps.title: Join a book club.
steps.content: Join a book club. If you love reading, see if your local library or community has a book club you can join. This is a great way to meet people of all ages and lifestyles with a similar interest—books! You may even be able to find a group on social media. Pro tip: If you can’t find a book club in your area, make one! Gather up your friends, choose a book to read together, and plan a day to meet back up and discuss what you read.

steps.title: Go to community events.
steps.content: Go to community events. Doing things in your local area can help you meet people your age who live right next door! See if your town has any festivals, farmer’s markets, or community events going on. Then, don’t hesitate to talk to anyone who seems interesting—you never know what connections you’ll make. As Wang explains, “The most important thing to meeting new people is to take initiative and put yourself out there.”

steps.title: Join a recreational league.
steps.content: Join a recreational league. Playing sports isn’t just for kids and the pros—you can do it too! As Wang suggests, being a part of a team is a great way to connect with people quickly. After all, you must learn to work together to reach a common goal. Check with your local community center or gym to see if any recreational leagues are happening in your area. Pro tip: If you don’t want to be a part of an official local team, create your own. Get together with a bunch of sports-loving friends and plan days to go out and play!

steps.title: Go somewhere new.
steps.content: Go somewhere new. Take a trip to someplace new that interests you. Maybe that’s a museum, concert, or sporting event. Then, challenge yourself to talk to at least one person (like someone sitting next to you). Who knows? You may just find a friend with similar interests! [3] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Nervous to go somewhere by yourself? Ask an old friend or partner to come with you (just make sure they’re in on the challenge, too.)

steps.title: Connect through social media.
steps.content: Connect through social media. Social media groups are a great way to meet like-minded people of your age with similar interests. Join a Facebook group or Discord chat to engage with others about things you like. Who knows? An online connection can quickly transform into an in-person friendship! Employee relations expert Jeffrey Fermin recommends “websites like Meetup, forums related to specific hobbies, and Facebook groups” to connect with people with “shared values and beliefs.” Remember to be safe when connecting with others online! If you decide to meet in person, schedule a video chat beforehand, tell a friend where you’re going, and meet in a public place. [4] X Trustworthy Source Rape, Abuse, and Incest National Network Largest anti-sexual assault organization in the US providing support and advocacy for survivors Go to source

steps.title: Open up with coworkers.
steps.content: Open up with coworkers. Sometimes, the bestest friends are hiding right under your nose! Turn your coworkers into friends by participating in work social events, talking about your life outside of work, and inviting them to casual outings. [5] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Pro tip: Bound over similar interests and hobbies with your coworkers. For instance, if they love books, invite them out for a cup of coffee and bookstore browse one weekend.

steps.title: Connect with friends of friends.
steps.content: Connect with friends of friends. Ask your current besties to introduce you to their other friend circles. Go to parties and try to hang out with others in large groups. This is an excellent way to meet new people with similar connections (especially if you’re a bit shy—you’ll know at least one person there). As Fermin reiterates, “Your friends and family might already know someone who shares your values. Attend social gatherings, parties, or events where they introduce you to their circle. You never know who you might resonate with.”

steps.title: Busy schedules and responsibilities can make it harder to make friends.
steps.content: Busy schedules and responsibilities can make it harder to make friends. When you’re a kid, all you have to worry about is what’s for lunch in the cafeteria and memorizing your best friend's handshake. Nowadays, you’ve got bills to pay, a job to go to, and maybe even kids of your own to feed. The time commitments you have as an adult can make it more challenging to make friends. After all, maintaining friendships is like a full-time job, and you already have one of those! But even though it may be harder, it’s not impossible. [6] X Research source Put meetings and check-ins with friends on your calendar to coordinate your schedule and still make time for them. [7] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source

steps.title: A fear of rejection can make it difficult to make friends.
steps.content: A fear of rejection can make it difficult to make friends. As an adult, you’ve likely had your fair share of rejections. Past friendships, relationships, trials, and other tribulations have tested your courage. And even if you came out stronger, you may still hesitate to trust others. The fear of being rejected may cause you to close up and become a bit of a hermit—know that you’re not alone. [8] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Challenge your fear by trying new things and stepping out of your comfort zone . If you’re struggling to overcome your fear, reach out for help. Talk to a therapist to better understand your past and learn more about yourself.

steps.title: Communicate your boundaries.
steps.content: Communicate your boundaries. Don’t hesitate to say when something’s working and isn’t working. [9] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source As an adult, you’ve been through your fair share of friendships before—use what you’ve learned from them to maintain a healthy friendship. Boundaries can look like not making plans after 9 PM on weekdays, saying you’re unavailable when you’re unwell, or not sharing everything about your personal life.

steps.title: Make time to squeeze in a chat.
steps.content: Make time to squeeze in a chat. Do your best to make time for a newfound friend. For friendships to last, both parties need to feel like they’re supported and valued. [10] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source So, turn your lunch break into a friendship date or give them a quick phone call on the way home from work. Schedule a time to connect with them to show that you truly care. Now, this doesn’t mean you should neglect your needs. Be aware of your own boundaries, but also make sure to check in with new pals.

steps.title: Show up when it matters.
steps.content: Show up when it matters. It’s okay to be the first one to reach out. If someone’s going through a tough time or you’ve disconnected along the way, send them a text or sweet message. Even a simple gesture can help keep the friendship alive. After all, no one wants to feel alone. [11] X Research source For instance, send them flowers if they’ve lost a loved one. If they’re sick, offer to grab their groceries for them.

steps.title: Know that friendships can change.
steps.content: Know that friendships can change. Friendships don’t last forever, and that’s okay. People are forever evolving, which means you and your friendships constantly change. View friendships as a chapter in the story of your life—they may be present for one and not the other. [12] X Research source Coming to terms with this can help you stay present in the moment and value your friend even more.

steps.title: Making friends is important because friendship improves your overall health.
steps.content: Making friends is important because friendship improves your overall health. Believe it or not, having friends can impact your physical and mental health. Meaningful connections help you feel wanted, welcomed, and supported, and as an adult, you need that more than ever. Take a look at these surprising benefits to friendship: [13] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Combats loneliness and social isolation Improves self-esteem Helps you live longer [14] X Research source Relieves stress Healthy heart health [15] X Research source Increases productivity

steps.title: If you’re a parent, take advantage of your child’s social outings.
steps.content: If you’re a parent, take advantage of your child’s social outings. Get buddy-buddy with your child’s friend’s parents, and make yourself known at school or daycare functions. When setting up a playdate for your child, set one up for yourself too! While the kids play, chit-chat with the other parents. Let your child’s social life help fuel yours. Think of making new friends like dating. Ask get-to-know-you questions to see if you can vibe with anyone. Talk about your favorite musicians, movies, foods, and hobbies.

steps.title: “I was able to meet new people doing activities I enjoyed.”
steps.content: “I was able to meet new people doing activities I enjoyed.” “After college, I had a really hard time making friends. All of my friends had moved away—we had all gone in different directions to pursue our careers. Sure, we were able to connect over the phone, but it wasn’t the same as being around them in person. So, I started branching out into the community. I participated in library events, attended a few cycling classes, and even starred in a few community theater productions. I met a lot of people by doing things I enjoyed.” - Staff Writer Aly R. Her advice: “Don’t be afraid to try new things on your own! While it may be scary at first, you never know who you’ll meet or who you’ll strike up a conversation with. Most of the new friends I’ve made were during moments when I was by myself.”

steps.title: “Discord servers can be a great way to meet new people.”
steps.content: “Discord servers can be a great way to meet new people.” “Discord is an online social platform that allows users to make "servers" dedicated to a special topic or fandom. While it can be intimidating to join a big server at first, it can be easy to link up with people who have similar interests and passions as you. Just search ‘[topic or fandom] discord server’ online and see what results pop up!" - Staff Writer Janice T.
